description.narrative:
2014 års humanitära stöd till IOM baseras på ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till 2013 års beslut. Insatsen gäller humanitärt stöd. Tidigare stöd består dels av ett tvåårigt instutitions- och kapacitetsstöd till IOM för att utveckla och förbättra organisationens humanitära kapacitet och ramverk, dels av ett treårigt, oöronmärkt stöd till IOMs snabbinsatsmekanism Migration Emergency Funding Mechanism - MEFM. Den största delen av 2013 års finansiering utgörs emellertid av stöd till IOMs landspecifika projekt inom ramen för de FN-ledda gemensamma humanitära landplanerna. För 2013 omfattades följande fyra länder av detta stöd: Haiti, Kenya, Mali samt Zimbabwe.
Genom ett kompletterande insatsbeslut avser Sida förlänga sitt stöd mot IOMs landsspecifika projekt 2014 till följande fem länder: Haiti (förlängning av 2013 års program), Kenya, Irak, Yemen och Bangladesh.
I och med detta kompletterande insatsbeslut kommer den sammanlagda insatsen att uppgå till 92 MSEK och fördelas enligt följande:
2013 Humanitär kapacitetsutveckling - 4 MSEK Snabbinsatsmekanism - 2 MSEK Haiti - 14 MSEK Kenya - 6 MSEK Mali - 5 MSEK Zimbabwe - 4 MSEK Total summa 35 MSEK
2014 Humanitär kapacitetsutveckling - 4 MSEK Snabbinsatsmekanism - 2 MSEK Haiti - 10 MSEK Kenya - 5 MSEK Irak - 19 MSEK Yemen - 10 MSEK Bangladesh - 5 MSEK Total summa 55 MSEK
2015 Snabbinsatsmekanism - 2 MSEK Total summa 2 MSEK
Notera att Sidas budget för 2013 på s.1 i detta beslut ej är korrekt. Detta beror på att det inte är tekniskt möjligt att koppla samman de två separata plus-insatserna för IOMs kapacitets- respektive landstöd.

The 2014 humanitarian support to IOM is based on a supplementary decision to the decision made in 2013. Previous support to IOM consists of a two-year institutional and capacity support to develop and improve the organization's humanitarian capacity and framework,and a three-year, un-earmarked support to IOMs rapid response mechanism – Migration Emergency Funding Mechanism (MEFM). The largest part of the 2013 support however is directed to IOMs country-specific projects under the joint UN-led humanitarian appeal. For 2013 the support targeted Haiti, Kenya, Mali and Zimbabwe.
Sida intends to extend its support to IOMs country-specific projects in 2014 to the following four countries: Haiti (extension of the 2013 program), Kenya, Iraq and Yemen. With this supplementary decision, the combined humanitarian support to IOM for 2013-2015 will amount to 92 MSEK, allocated as follows:
2013-14 Humanitarian capacity development - 4 MSEK Rapid response mechanism - 2 MSEK Haiti - 14 MSEK Kenya - 6 MSEK Mali - 5 MSEK Zimbabwe - 4 MSEK Total sum 35 MSEK
2014-15 Humanitarian capacity development - 4 MSEK Rapid response mechanism - 2 MSEK Haiti - 10 MSEK Kenya - 5 MSEK Iraq - 19 MSEK Yemen - 10 MSEK Bangladesh - 5 MSEK Total sum 55 MSEK
2015 Rapid response mechanism - 2 MSEK Total sum 2 MSEK

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: This is the fourth interim report approximately 2.5 years into the project (3 year project) that aims at improving the ability of IOM to deliver on its commitments, strengths and goals through donor investment in four main components.
The results achieved during the reporting period (6 months) are: Component 1 . 6 missions tested modalities for implementing the policy framework. - IOM representatives from 14 missions participated in the framing workshop for the Progressive Resolution of Displacement Situations Framework and the pilot training. - 7 IOM country missions benefited from ad hoc support for the mainstreaming of protection within their project, programmes and strategies. - Field testing of IOM's new humanitarian policy in six countries supported the document's finalization and helped evaluate the policy. - Targeted partners were further consulted on the development of IOM's PHA with dedicated NGO consultations. - Finalization and endorsement by the SCPF of the IOM humanitarian policy, - Protection mainstreaming internal guidance note and practical tools across the project life-cycle finalised. - New Framework entitled The Progressive Resolution of Displacement drafted as result of consultation and review of good practices. - Targeted partners were further consulted on the development of IOM's PHA, with dedicated NGO consultations taking place. - The Humanitarian Policy Platform has been consolidated and a set of outreach tools have been defined and launched according to the outreach plan agreed upon by the Humanitarian Policy Working Group. - Protection mainstreaming internal guidance note and practical tools across the project life-cycle finalised.
Component 2 - Rapid response teams were deployed to support both level 2 and 3 emergencies. - IOM responded to five Level 3 emergencies. - Rapid Response Teams were deployed to support emergency responses in L3 and other crises. - The second ERIT was successfully completed, attended by 23 participants. - DOE roster contains over 100 profiles. - Consultations with technical and field staff continued to internally review the EOM toolkit. - Through Norwegian separate funding, a warehouse has been set up in Manila.
Component 3 - IOM DTM training materials were developed and applied during the first global DTM Training held in Tnz attended by 33 IOM staff - During the reporting period, DTM has been setup, implemented and/or expanded in every major emergency operation.
Component 4 - To inform camp managers and camp coordinators, DTM information is available online, providing access to timely and accurate data on internal displacement. Enhanced analysis of data is supported through the SAS visual analytic platform. - The DTM Rapid Response Officer participated in the Protection Information Management workshop. - Capacity building events were held to increase the capacity of national authorities, partners and IOM staff to respond to and manage displaced populations. - Continued support was provided to global shelter coordination forums, training and policies. - IOM logistics emergency catalogue edition I, version 7, was launched. - Field support and participation in multiagency meetings was continued on CCCM and shelter, including the Global Shelter Cluster meeting and Coordination Workshop etc. - IOM Cash based transfer document was developed.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
